greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} (-1)^k*binomial(k,2)^3*binomial(n,k)^3.
comment: Let d(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} (-1)^k*binomial(n,k)^3. Clearly, by symmetry of the binomial coefficients we have d(2*n + 1) = 0. Dixon's identity is the result d(2*n) = (-1)^n*(3*n)!/n!^3. A generalization is: for r a nonnegative integer there holds Sum_{k = 0..n} (-1)^k*binomial(k,r)^3*binomial(n,k)^3 = (-1)^r*binomial(n,r)^3*d(n - r). This is the case r = 2. See A273630 (case r = 1) and A245086 (case r = 0).
link: P. Bala, A generalization of Dixon's identity
J. Ward, 100 Years of Dixon's Identity, Irish Mathematical Society Bulletin 27, 46-54, 1991
mathematica: Table[Sum[(-1)^k*Binomial[k, 2]^3 Binomial[n, k]^3, {k, 0, n}], {n, 0, 27}] (* _Michael De Vlieger_, Jul 22 2016 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = sum(k=0, n, (-1)^k*binomial(k, 2)^3*binomial(n, k)^3) \\ _Felix Fröhlich_, Jul 22 2016
(MAGMA) [&+[(-1)^k*Binomial(k,2)^3*Binomial(n,k)^3: k in [0..n]]: n in [0..70]]; // _Vincenzo Librandi_, Jul 23 2016
results.author: _Peter Bala_, Jul 17 2016
